statement.text: Subclavian artery exposure provides access to the first and second portions of this major upper extremity and brachiocephalic vessel. The supraclavicular approach exposes the distal subclavian artery through an incision above the clavicle, requiring careful management of the phrenic nerve, brachial plexus, and thoracic duct. The infraclavicular approach provides access to the third portion (axillary artery). More extensive exposure may require clavicular resection or thoracotomy for the innominate origin.
statement.formal: Subclavian Exposure: Supraclavicular (incision above clavicle, divide scalene fat pad, anterior scalene muscle, identify artery behind scalenus anticus) | Infraclavicular (deltopectoral approach to axillary artery) | Critical: Phrenic nerve (on anterior scalene), brachial plexus (posterior/superior), thoracic duct (left side at venous angle)

explanation.intuition: The subclavian artery is the main highway from the chest to the arm, running behind the clavicle like a tunnel under a bridge. The supraclavicular approach is like coming down from above to access the tunnel entrance - you have to navigate around important 'cables' (the phrenic nerve to the diaphragm) and 'power lines' (the brachial plexus to the arm). The infraclavicular approach accesses the tunnel exit below the clavicle where it becomes the axillary artery.
explanation.key_insight: The key to safe subclavian exposure is understanding the scalene triangle - the artery runs behind the anterior scalene muscle, the phrenic nerve runs ON the anterior scalene (don't cut the muscle before identifying the nerve), and the brachial plexus is posterior and superior. On the left side, you must also be aware of the thoracic duct.
explanation.technical_details: Supraclavicular Approach: (1) Patient supine, head turned away, roll under shoulders; (2) Transverse incision 1-2cm above clavicle; (3) Divide platysma, clavicular head of SCM if needed; (4) Identify and retract external jugular vein; (5) Divide scalene fat pad (contains transverse cervical vessels); (6) Identify phrenic nerve on anterior scalene surface; (7) Mobilize and protect phrenic nerve; (8) Divide anterior scalene muscle; (9) Expose subclavian artery; (10) Identify vertebral artery origin, internal thoracic artery origin. Left-sided: Identify and ligate thoracic duct if encountered. Extended exposure: (1) Divide clavicle or resect medial portion; (2) Ligate subclavian vein if needed; (3) For more proximal control, median sternotomy may be required.
common_misconceptions: You can divide the anterior scalene without finding the phrenic nerve - this causes diaphragm paralysis
The thoracic duct is only on the left - 80% left, but can be right or bilateral
Clavicle resection is always needed - supraclavicular approach provides good exposure for most cases
The brachial plexus is at risk from the supraclavicular approach - it's posterior/superior, relatively protected

definitions_glossary.anterior_scalene: Muscle from C3-C6 to first rib, subclavian artery runs behind it
definitions_glossary.phrenic_nerve: Nerve to diaphragm, runs on anterior surface of anterior scalene
definitions_glossary.brachial_plexus: Network of nerves to upper extremity, posterior and superior to subclavian artery
definitions_glossary.thoracic_duct: Main lymphatic duct, empties at left venous angle (jugular-subclavian junction)
definitions_glossary.vertebral_artery: First branch of subclavian, runs posteriorly into transverse foramina

indications: Subclavian artery stenosis/occlusion with subclavian steal
contraindications: Prior clavicular fracture with extensive scarring (consider alternative approach)

technique.positioning: Supine, head turned away, shoulder roll, ipsilateral arm at side

supraclavicular_approach.incision: Transverse, 1-2cm above clavicle, from SCM to trapezius
layers: Clavicular head of SCM (divide if needed)
Scalene fat pad (divide carefully - lymphatics, transverse cervical vessels)
Anterior scalene muscle (after protecting phrenic nerve)

key_structures.phrenic_nerve: On anterior scalene - MUST identify before dividing muscle
key_structures.transverse_cervical_artery: May cross field, divide if needed
key_structures.thoracic_duct: Left side, at venous angle - ligate if injured

steps: Identify and retract external jugular vein
Divide clavicular head of SCM if needed
Identify phrenic nerve on anterior scalene
Identify vertebral artery origin if needed

infraclavicular_approach.use: For axillary artery access, bypass inflow, trauma

complications.manifestation: Diaphragm paralysis, dyspnea, elevated hemidiaphragm on CXR
complications.prevention: Always identify nerve ON anterior scalene before dividing muscle
complications.management: Usually traction injury recovers; permanent injury may need diaphragm plication

complications.prevention: Careful dissection at left venous angle, ligate lymphatics
complications.management: Ligate if identified; chylothorax needs chest tube, dietary modification, possible reoperation
Usually traction injury recovers over months

complications.prevention: Identify vein early, control before artery

definition.@value: Surgical exposure of the subclavian artery through supraclavicular or infraclavicular approach for vascular procedures

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Subclavian and Axillary Artery Exposure.
Atlas of Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy. Thoracic Outlet Exposures.

learning_objectives: Describe the anatomy of the subclavian artery and thoracic outlet
Perform supraclavicular exposure of the subclavian artery
Identify and protect the phrenic nerve during anterior scalenectomy
Recognize and manage thoracic duct injury
clinical_pearls: The phrenic nerve runs ON the anterior scalene - find it before dividing the muscle
On the left side, always be aware of the thoracic duct at the venous angle
The subclavian artery is BEHIND the anterior scalene, not in front of it
For more proximal control, you may need to resect the medial clavicle or do a sternotomy
The vertebral artery is the first branch - look posteriorly to find it

medicalCode.description: Inspection of subclavian artery, open approach
